inlineContent.text: And just like that, I’m off and running. I can’t remember the last time I had an experience like this. This seems like an iPhone moment. The entire Notion environment and related ecosystem is very easy to use.  I was able to import more than 11 years of memories in less than a couple of hours. I was able to start processing those memories in more dynamic ways in less than 12 hrs. The key ingredients of the second brain are here.

However, the concept behind Notion is one that I am familiar with. It looks and feels like a far off concept I once envisioned is now here. “Workstreaming” is a corporate level speak for what is more commonly known as Kanban. Coming from JPMorgan, I thought it would be cool if everyone had this. That’s why my original concepts were called “wrkstrm”.

Finally, I must complain. I don’t think Notion would have gotten here without React Native. Yet as a native developer, I don’t like it. Every now and then I see flickering, generic transitions or some other known side effect of essentially running a web browser. I hate that. Then again, have we reached the uncanny valley of web development? Will we be there in 2 years, 5 years? At that point will native have advantages?
Using Notion raises as many questions as it answers.

In the world of programming languages, Swift has emerged as a dynamic and versatile option. Its type inference feature, while powerful, isn’t without its quirks. Like any technological innovation, Swift’s type inference has its own set of performance considerations that developers should be aware of. In this blog post, we’ll delve into the fascinating realm of Swift’s type inference and explore how it can sometimes impose performance penalties.

doc://me.rismay.site/documentation/Risma.title: Navigating the Performance Penalties of Swift Type Inference

TL;DR: Apple has been refining their location APIs opportunistically to improve battery life.

I previously posted that I returned my Late 2013 13” rMBP after I encountered the dreaded unresponsive keyboard glitch. This is a bit disingenuous because the ultimate reason I returned the notebook was to purchase a more powerful version of the same laptop after the Keyboard/Trackpad problems were confirmed to be software issues. However, when I went to look at my buying options, I discover that Apple was offering the original 2012 15” rMBP for $1600. That’s $500 off for a laptop that comes with a 1 year warranty. This post is simply to help those wondering: Should you pay $100 more for a refurbished original 15” Retina Macbook Pro vs a new Late 2013 13” MacBook Pro Retina?

doc://me.rismay.site/documentation/Risma.title: $1500 13” Late 2013 rMBP vs $1600 15” 2012 rMBP? Portability vs Performance
